subject: Fix for hwmontemp sensor to avoid invoking same sensor
commitMessage:
Fix for hwmontemp sensor to avoid invoking same sensor

Refactored the code by constructing a map to store the sensor bus &
address as key and sensor information as value. Instead of iterating
sensor configuration for every hwmon path, this will make the code
efficient by configuring sensor details before iterating hwmon paths.

Moreover, once a sensor name is found and all the sensor names under
each config is constructed, then, sensor config from the configMap is
removed. Therefore, this will avoid invoking a constructor for same
sensor under different hwmon paths.

Tested: Tested in Facebook YosemiteV2 platform and verified the
hwmontemp sensors.

Signed-off-by: Jayashree Dhanapal <jayashree-d@hcl.com>
Change-Id: Iae06b2e1d4245e2f455b1366924694a55d3b0a05

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 9f3a74edba3a0379f4b172ed998d9aae2101a920
Please also test that changing a configuration parameter (threshold, ect) causes the sensor to get reconstructed.

Hi Matt,

Could you please test this patch in your platform and let me know the results.

Thanks
What do I look for to know if it's fixed or not?
Please apply this patch in your platform, and check whether sensors related to your platform are created in dbus and all the threshold properties and values are configured correctly.
Seems to work OK. (though we weren't having any problems in the first place)
I think you can leave this off, or is there a reason it to have a single empty entry?

looking at this, I'm not quite sure how this fixes the issue.  sensorName comes from baseConfigMap, which comes from base configuration.  Are there duplicates in the base configuration that's causing this issue?

The below mentioned entity configuration is used in my platform. Here, same "Bus" and "Address" is used for 2 sensors named "SP_OUTLET_TEMP" and "SP_OUTLET_REMOTE_TEMP" for the paths "/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon2/temp1_input" and "/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon2/temp2_input". When the first path is identified, it will compare the bus and addr of the path with the baseconfigMap and invoke the constructor for "SP_OUTLET_TEMP". Then it looks for "Name1" for same sensor and check the path "/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon2/temp2_input", then it will invoke the constructor for "SP_OUTLET_REMOTE_TEMP". When the loop iterates for next path, it will check and skip the path if it is already searched.
{
    "Address": "0x4f",
    "Bus": 9,
    "Name": "SP_OUTLET_TEMP",
    "Name1": "SP_OUTLET_REMOTE_TEMP",
    "Thresholds": [
            {
                "Direction": "greater than",
                "Name": "upper critical",
                "Severity": 1,
                "Value": 70
             }
     ],
     "Type": "TMP421"
}

In the below patch, it has more than one sensor type with different address for devices DPS310 and SI7020. In the previous code, when the loop iterates for next path, it will check and skip the path if it is already searched. Therefore, "continue" is removed in the below patch, so the loop will not skip the path after finding the first sensor of the device, eventhough it is already searched.

https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/commit/544e7dc58cecef898fe7d684c3ba0fbce178cf2d#diff-bfc8d7ed4ade4b3519ad3b7fe091f9c79a60faf8a26f410c1568e5341b22b7abL96

In my conf, when the loop iterates for next path, it will have bus and addr value same as the previous path. Therefore, it will again invoke the constructor for "SP_OUTLET_TEMP" and "SP_OUTLET_REMOTE_TEMP".

Hence, by checking the sensor name with previous names, we can avoid invoking the constructor for same sensor.
Thanks for the detailed explanation. I think a better and more efficient way to fix this is to remove the config from the sensorConfigs once a match is found and a sensor has been constructed,

I have removed a sensor after it is constructed using erase(). Here "sensorConfigurations" map is declared as const, so the map cannot be modified, therefore, I have removed const. Whether is that accepted ?

https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/HwmonTempMain.cpp#L153

Looks like the callback function is called by the destructor, so the object would be destroyed after the callback. Removing the constness seems to be ok for me.

https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/include/Utils.hpp#L314

< https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/HwmonTempMain.cpp#L153

What is this for?

> Looks like the callback function is called by the destructor, so the object would be destroyed after the callback. Removing the constness seems to be ok for me.
> 
> https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/include/Utils.hpp#L314 

Thanks.

> < https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/HwmonTempMain.cpp#L153
> 
> What is this for?

sorry, I pointed out some other line instead of const.
I am wondering whether there should be some check like if (sensor != nullptr) making sure line352 and/or line399 ran.
Since, there are 2 object invoking constructor in different places, I have used flag to check the nullptr.
'flag' is a pretty generic name.  Could you maybe name it something that indicates what it's used for?

I think if you want use a flag,  sensorCreated is a better name and it can be set to true after the make_shared call.

But as you can see, sensor will not be nullptr only when make_shared is called at least once
Sorry, did not mentioned this earlier. This needs to get reset for each sensorConfig, so move to later, refer to other inline comments

Hmm, I think theoretically only baseConfiguration should be removed, not the entire path. Not sure in reality, if there is only 1 : 1 relation from Path to baseConfig.

This review seems would work in this service too, but it does involves a bigger refactor effort. But has the added benefit of being more efficient. 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/49254

> Hmm, I think theoretically only baseConfiguration should be removed, not the entire path. Not sure in reality, if there is only 1 : 1 relation from Path to baseConfig.
> 

.

in line 254 and 265.

Could you please confirm this ?

Yes, if it enables only the specific baseConfig that is used to create the sensor to be deleted for the configMap created @ 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/49254/7/src/PSUSensorMain.cpp#334
I have refactored hwmon code like PSUSensor patch and also added sensorCreated flag to remove the sensor config after sensor is constructed.
I tried this version of the patch, and the Pressure sensor disappeared.
Could you please comment line 456 and check in your platform. So that, we can confirm whether pressure sensor is removed due to erasing config or refactored code.
when I commented out that line the sensor was there again

@Matt, Do you have multiple sensors with the same bus and address?
If that is true, I am wondering, whether the config key needs to be bus/ address + sensor type or interface
Yea, we have a dsp310 that provides both temperature and pressure.

In the new patchset, I have added a condition to check the typeName of sensor in line 397 and 449. If the typeName is neither pressure nor humidity, then sensorCreated flag will be true and it will erase the config.

Whether this approach is fine ?

If not, in the first patchset, I have created a vector to store the sensor names and will check if the sensor name is already created or not. If it is already created, it will skip and iterate to next path.

Please provide your suggestions.

I still think identify and removed the already consumed config from the iteration loop is more efficient. 
Can you share or point me to the configuration file for these sensors?
Seems like addinng typeName to the ConfigKey may work?

https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/configurations/Blyth.json
The DPS310 has temp and pressure and the SI7020 has temp and humidity.

There's also the TMP423 family of devices that have multiple temps per device.
Hmm, I would expect the 2nd sensor (name1) would be created at line 419 loop before the erase config. Are they not under the same hwmon path?

the filesystem looks like:

/sys/bus/iio/devices/iio:device1# ls
in_humidityrelative_offset  in_humidityrelative_scale   in_temp_raw                 name                        power                       uevent
in_humidityrelative_raw     in_temp_offset              in_temp_scale               of_node                     subsystem


/sys/bus/iio/devices/iio:device2# ls
in_pressure_input               in_temp_input                   name                            subsystem
in_pressure_oversampling_ratio  in_temp_oversampling_ratio      of_node                         uevent
in_pressure_sampling_frequency  in_temp_sampling_frequency      power

Thanks, I understand now. 
Add name to ConfigKey can work. 
Or add vector <names> to the configMap. Remove the name when that sensor is created and erase the config if the vector <names> is empty. 
Cost of generating such config map need to be evaluated.
I would expect it still is more efficient than looping through all the configs for each path. But performance benefit will depend on system config.

In the latest patchset, I have added sensor name as vector in SensorConfig struct(line 169) and erased the name once the sensor is created in both the places(line 411 and 460). If the vector is empty, then it will erase the configMap.
This approach looks good to me. Just one minor comment from my perspective.

Addressed all the review comments and submitted a new patchset.

@Matt, Please check the latest patchset in your platform.

How about:

  auto operator<=>(const SensorConfigKey&) const = default;

The below error shown in CI while using "auto operator<=>(const SensorConfigKey&) const = default;"

"use nullptr [modernize-use-nullptr,-warnings-as-errors]"
That makes it seem like clang (used in clang-tidy) doesn't fully support the spaceship operator from C++20 yet.  Looking at their status it seems like maybe it'll show up in Clang 14. 😭
ok, for now, I'll keep this as bool operator. After clang-14 updated, I'll change and submit this part alone as new patch.
This seems really fancy for what you're doing.  Is it necessary to use a reference_wrapper on all these or can you just use a copy?
Since key is const, not able to use std::move().

With https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/50204 I removed the trace for when there is a tempX_input file in sysfs but no config for it, so I think you can just remove this trace too.
Please don't limit to Name1, include all NameX using a loop similar to line421

Hi Ed / Patrick,

Could you please provide your suggestion/approval for this patch.

Thanks.
A few minor comments.  Code could be merged as is if desired.

Hi Patrick,

I have addressed all the comments. Could you please provide your suggestions/approval for this patch.

Thanks
Shouldn't the key be moved too?

I am getting below error in CI for std::move(key).

error: std::move of the variable 'key' of the trivially-copyable type 'SensorConfigKey' has no effect; remove std::move() [performance-move-const-arg,-warnings-as-errors]
minor preference for std::ranges::find operations now with C++20 (since it cuts down the verbosity of having to specify the endpoints).
Should this be a vector so we don't lose the index information?  Ie, Name = index 0, Name 1 = index 1, ect.

Please just rely on get like the old code did, or alternatively, do a get_if<uint64_t> if you're not planning on throwing the exception.  I suspect the compiler is going to have a tough time optimizing this one, so we should give it help.

> Please just rely on get like the old code did, or alternatively, do a get_if<uint64_t> if you're not planning on throwing the exception.  I suspect the compiler is going to have a tough time optimizing this one, so we should give it help.

@Ed, I don't really understand this comment.  Why would using a lighter-weight function be worse for optimization than a heavy-weight function where we discard the results?

The code for the two is pretty similar...

https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/blob/16e2427f50c208dfe07d07f18009969502c25dc8/libstdc%2B%2B-v3/include/std/variant#L1134

https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/blob/16e2427f50c208dfe07d07f18009969502c25dc8/libstdc%2B%2B-v3/include/std/variant#L1085
isn't this logic now duplicated with line 208?  Can we just index into SensorConfig.name to get these values instead of going all the way back to the json config?
In line 424, sensor name is erased when it calls the constructor. Therefore, the index will be changed in the vector, so we can't get the sensor names based on index.
Why is this case needed?  When would hwmonName be empty?

When hwmon path is identified, it will invoke the constructor for the sensor and if it has "Name1" in a config, it will construct for that sensor. When the hwmon path iterates, the path for "Name1" will be again doing the same process since the bus and address for 2 sensors is same.

For each config, if all the sensor name like Name, Name1, Name2 ... is called in one iteration of hwmon path, then the hwmonName will be empty and config will be removed.

Hi Ed,

I have addressed all the comments. Could you please provide your suggestions/approval for this patch.

Thanks

Much of this patch looks remarkably similar to what I wrote in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/49254.

Could we perhaps share some logic between the two instead of duplicating it?

Sure, Do you have any approach for this ?

Are you suggesting by moving the common code in separate file and access those function from HwmonTemp and PSU Sensor?

Is there any patch submitted in gerrit for this ?

One option is to do it in steps:
1. Add the new APIs in a common place.
2. Modify each service to adopt the new API separately.

While it would be good to refactor some of this code to be common if there is some crossover with PSU, I think that should be done in a separate commit.  This commit is an attempt to fix code that Bruce broke back in December.  We have other platforms (ex. Bletchley) now using Bruce's code, so we shouldn't revert that, but we need to fix the regression it introduced in the Yv2 platform.  We're going on almost 2 months now of breakage.
If this is to fix a regression. Let's get this in first and do the refactor as follow up improvement
@Ed, are you OK with current change and defer refactor as a follow up improvement?
